facilityName.title: Facility & Permit Number
facilityName.content: Indicate the complete name of the facility and the air permit number issued by the regulating agency.

images.alt: Example of correctly filled facility name and permit

address.title: Facility Address
address.content: Indicate the physical address of the facility not the mailing address.

facilityContact.title: Facility Contact
facilityContact.content: Indicate the name and phone number of the designated facility contact.

sourceCoordinates.title: Source Coordinates
sourceCoordinates.content: If the observer has access to GPS, they should record the coordinates of the source being observed. For larger facilities, this can help distinguish the subject source from others.

sourceEquipmentDescription.title: Source Equipment Description
sourceEquipmentDescription.content: Describe the source of the emissions being observed. This is not the stack or emission point - this is the equipment or process that is producing the emissions. Indicate the type of equipment, color, make, model and any other descriptive features.

sourceEquipmentId.title: Source Equipment ID
sourceEquipmentId.content: The facility’s air permit should contain an identification number (such as Emission Point #1 or EP-1) for the source. Alternatively, the facility may have an in-house ID for the source. If available, also record the serial number of the source equipment.

sourceEquipmentMode.title: Source Equipment Mode
sourceEquipmentMode.content: Indicate the production or operational rate of the source equipment. This information can be acquired from the operator of the source. Have the operator record the production rate during the observation.

controlEquipmentDescription.title: Control Equipment Description
controlEquipmentDescription.content: Indicate the type of equipment or process which is used to control emissions from the source. This information can be obtained from the source operator. Examples include baghouses, scrubbers, thermal oxidizers and cyclones for point-source emissions. Examples for fugitive emissions include water spray, inherent rock moisture and sweeping for fugitive emissions.

controlEquipmentOperatingMode.title: Control Equipment Operating Mode
controlEquipmentOperatingMode.content: The capacity or performance of most modern control methods are monitored and recorded. This information can be obtained from the source operator. Different types of controls have different measuring methods. Baghouses measure pressure differential. A thermal oxidizer may measure the destruction efficiency of VOCs. Fugitive emission controls, such as water spray, are measured in gallons per hour.

images.caption: Differential pressure gauages are often found on baghouses.

emissionPoint.title: Emission Point Description
emissionPoint.content:
Indicate the physical characteristics of the emission point. Point source emissions usually have a stack or vent as their emission point. Describe the height, color and size of the emission point to ensure it can be distinguished from other points.

 The emission point of fugitive emissions can vary within the subject source equipment being observed. They do not have a defined emission point. Describe the point in the process where emissions are observed. Example: Tail pulley of subject conveyor

observationPointHeight.title: Observation Point - Height
observationPointHeight.content:
This is the vertical height between the observer and the observation point. Please note: the observation point is not always the emission point. It is the point in the plume where opacity is highest and water vapor is not present. If there are no visible emissions, indicate the height of the stack exit.

There are “Start” and “End” fields because the observer may have to move during the observations or the observation point may change.

observationPointDistance.title: Observation Point - Distance
observationPointDistance.content: This is the horizontal distance between the observer and the observation point. Record the distance at the begging and end of the test. The distance may change if the observer moves or if the observation point changes.

observationPointDirection.title: Observation Point - Direction
observationPointDirection.content: This is the direction from the observer’s position to the observation point. Degrees (225°) should be used instead of cardinal directions (N, S, E, W). Record the direction at the beginning of the test and at the completion of the test. The direction may change during the test if the observer moves or if the observation point changes.

observationPointAngle.title: Observation Point - Angle
observationPointAngle.content: This is the vertical angle between the observer’s position and the observation point. The angle must be less than 18° to prevent performing a slant angle correction (this will be covered later). If the observer does not have a device to measure the angle, they must stand at least three times the height of the observation point. For example, if the observation point height is 50 feet, the observer's position must be at least 150 feet away to ensure the viewing angle is less than 18°.

images.caption: The observation angle should be less than 18°.

distanceBetweenEmissionPointAndObservati.title: Distance Between Emission Point & Observation Point
distanceBetweenEmissionPointAndObservati.content: Indicate the estimated distance between the emission point (stack exit) to the observation point. For most plumes, the distance between the observation point and emission point is equal to the diameter of the emission point. If the emission point has a diameter of 6’, the observation point would be approximately 6’ from the emission point. The only time the observation point will be significantly further than 1 diameter is in the presence of an attached steam plume or reacting plume.

images.alt: Distance Between Emission Point & Observation Point example

plumeShape.title: Plume Shape
plumeShape.content: Indicate which of the five plume shapes most closely resembles the subject plume. If no visible emissions are present, write “NA” for 'Not Applicable'.

images.caption: Coning plume shape. Refer to previous section for other plume shapes.

emissionType.title: Emission Type
emissionType.content: Indicate the type of emission from the subject source.

emissionColor.title: Emission Color
emissionColor.content: Indicate the color of the emission at the beginning and completion of the test. In certain situations, the color can change during the test. If there are no visible emissions, write “NA” in the fields.

waterVaporPlume.title: Water Vapor Plume
waterVaporPlume.content: If there is water vapor (steam) plume present, indicate if it is attached or detached from the stack.

backgroundAndColor.title: Background & Color
backgroundAndColor.content: Indicate what is being used as the background and the color of the background. Ideally, the background should have high-contrast with the emission color.

cloudCover.title: % Cloud Cover
cloudCover.content: Indicate the amount of cloud cover at the beginning and at the completion of the test. Report cloud cover as a percentage. Cloudless skies are 0%. Overcast skies are 100%.

ambientTemp.title: Ambient Temperature
ambientTemp.content: Indicate the temperature at the beginning and at the completion of the test.

windSpeed.title: Wind Speed
windSpeed.content: Indicate the speed of the wind at the beginning and at the completion of the test.

windDirection.title: Wind Direction
windDirection.content: Indicate the direction from which the wind is blowing at the beginning and at the completion of the test.

relativeHumidity.title: Relative Humidity
relativeHumidity.content: Indicate the relative humidity at the beginning of the test. This data can be acquired from a local weather station or with a handheld device.

wetBulbTemp.title: Wet Bulb Temperature
wetBulbTemp.content: This field only needs to be completed if the observer is unsure if the plume contains water vapor. The wet bulb temperature will help determine the probability of a steam plume. This topic is discussed in a subsequent section.

sketch.title: Source Layout Sketch
sketch.content:
Complete the source layout sketch at the end of the test. 

 - The location of the sun relative to the observer’s position should be indicated on the “Draw Sun” line. 

 - Using the key, draw the wind and plume symbols to indicate the direction of the wind and plume. 

 - Using a compass, draw an arrow indicating North relative to your observation position.

general.title: Form #
general.content: If the testing time for the source exceeds 60 minutes, multiple test forms may be needed. Remember - EPA Method 9 does not establish the duration of the test. Test durations are set by the regulation affecting the facility and are usually listed in the facility permit.

observationDateAndTime.title: Observation Date & Time
observationDateAndTime.content: Indicate the date and start and end time of the test. We recommend using the 24-hour military time format.

observations.title: Observations
observations.content:
Record observations in 5% increments every 15 seconds. The first recording occurs at the beginning of the test.

At least 6 minutes of continuous observations are needed to calculate a rolling average. Calculating opacity will be covered in a subsequent section.

averageOpacity.title: Highest Average Opacity
averageOpacity.content: After the test is complete, calculate the highest rolling average and input the value in this field.

readingsAbove.title: Number of Readings Above
readingsAbove.content:
Record the number of individual opacity readings that exceeded a specific opacity limit. The opacity limit is typically specified in the facility's permit.

For example: If the permit states 'No more than 3 readings above 20% opacity in one hour', you would write '20' in the first blank and the number of readings that exceeded 20% in the second blank.

observerNameAndSignature.title: Observer Name & Signature
observerNameAndSignature.content: Print and sign your name as it appears on your certification.

organization.title: Company/Organization
organization.content: Indicate the company or organization you represent.

certification.title: Certification
certification.content: Indicate the smoke school service provider who issued your certification and the date it was issued.  All EPA Method 9 certifications are valid for exactly 6 months.

comments.title: Comments
comments.content: Indicate events or situations that occurred during the test and affected the test. Examples include changes in atmospheric conditions, source malfunctions, other people present during the test and any conditions which affected the observations.The back of the test sheet or an additional piece of paper can also be used for comments.
